awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Recovering the Polyvalent Genealogies of Machine Learning, 1948 - 2017
awd_abstract_narration:
Machine learning techniques currently make "high-stakes" judgments in areas as diverse as criminal justice, credit risk, social welfare, hiring, and congressional redistricting. Such techniques make these decisions using patterns learned from historical social data. Emphasis on prediction rather than the circumstances of dataset creation have led to machine learning systems that preferentially target vulnerable populations for disparately adverse social judgments while making it more difficult for those subject to these decisions to protest unfair treatment. This study explores the limitations of such machine learning systems by tracing how technical and non-technical people, including funding agencies, have historically understood what machine learning systems could and should achieve. Particular care is given to the forms of "learning" valued by researchers during different moments in the 20th century, and to the emergence of theoretical concepts that were constrained and even defined by the capabilities of the available material devices. This work makes visible the efforts of women and men previously omitted in histories of artificial intelligence and machine learning, and develops a quantitative method to document how the innovations of a discipline are contingent upon interdisciplinary and transdisciplinary research networks. Finally, this project traces how the allocation of resources to particular research communities spurred scientific innovation in adjacent and seemingly unrelated academic research fields in the physical and social sciences. In this sense, the discipline of machine learning provides a useful case study for modeling the propagation of ideas across different subfields.

Both qualitative and quantitative historical research is employed. First, nine university and government archives are perused to reconstruct the institutional organizations, interpersonal research networks, and material computing devices available to machine learning and artificial intelligence researchers. Second, an investigation is conducted using a novel combination of topic modeling and word embeddings on a corpus of millions of full-text Association of Computing Machinery articles from 1950 to 2017 to trace how discursive influence propagates across disparate sub-disciplines. Four research products are generated: (1) a technical machine learning publication detailing the novel method used to analyze the article corpus, (2) a history of science article tracing the early history of machine learning, (3) a general audience "think piece" discussing the policy and ethical implications of contemporary machine learning research, (4) and the public release of the project code and the subsequent statistics generated from the article corpus. Digital copies of salient archive records discovered during this research study will be made freely available via Columbia University's Digital Repository, insofar as this is possible given the copyright and access restrictions of holding institutions. Archive materials collected and computational study of the article corpus will be used in the co-PI's doctoral dissertation exploring how machine learning has been used to classify individuals, imagine communities, and legislate forms of social and political evidence.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project provides an account of the diverse forms of "machine learning" that circulated across a patchwork of sites of pattern recognition research from the mid-1950s to late 1980s. It shows how these disparate fields were reimagined and consolidated as a subfield of artificial intelligence in the late 1980s and early 1990s. In the portable set of practices, methods, and strategies produced in these fields, analyzing large datasets became the preferred way for making decisions in situations of uncertainty and variability. Researchers hoped that these data-focused approaches would guide legal and political decision making. Drawing on original research from 15 archives in 3 countries, and an exploratory empirical study of a new corpus of millions of full-text journal articles and conference proceedings from the late 1940s - 1980s, the co-PI's dissertation, partially funded by the NSF, traces how pattern recognition researchers doing "machine learning" rooted their efforts in a particular conception of "creativity." They envisioned this form of creativity could facilitate hypothesis generation in scientific inquiry while also advancing a cosmopolitan view of human agency and human subjectivity. Expressing skepticism for simplistic notions of objective knowledge, these researchers argued that classifying data necessarily involved value judgments that neither logical deduction or empirical observation could justify. Far from a royal path to non-human objectivity, machine learning showed the need for human value making.

This alternative history of machine learning traces a multiplicity of different, even mutually exclusive, "machine learning" research trajectories across different communities, including the use of nominalist approaches to solve problems in so-called "ill-defined systems" where decisions had to be made in new situations for which no complete causal explanation or model was available. The partial and uneven rebranding of pattern recognition techniques as "machine learning" in late 1980s and early 1990s "artificial intelligence," the co-PI's dissertation demonstrates, was a response to the increasing status of research problems involving induction in "ill-defined systems," and an inability to compare the practical performance of different learning programs. A particular notion of creativity as a capacity to offer relevant alternative interpretations of the same data drove much early machine learning work. For many pattern recognition researchers this need to accommodate variability in data and answers was not merely a consequence of uncertainty, but reflected an ambiguity inherent in performing induction that the tripartite machine learning ontology of supervised, unsupervised, and reinforcement learning was intended to partially mitigate. The dissertation offers a novel and evidentially-grounded account of the history of AI and machine learning that challenges existing narratives about why certain machine learning approaches became ubiquitous in the twenty-first century. More broadly, the research suggests the need to cultivate new models for understanding institutionally-funded endeavors that span both scientific and engineering disciplines.

While contemporary machine learning systems are rightly criticized when they reproduce and reify prejudice, the dissertation shows that machine learning programs in the twentieth century were often valued because of their sensitivities to the idiosyncrasies of input data. Tracing how machine learning's sensitivity to data went from being valorized in the twentieth century to being vilified in the twenty-first, the dissertation explores how "context" became conflated with data sets. It further investigates how different notions of "efficacy" were intimately tied to what research problems were seen as important and the material computing practices that generated and constrained conceptions of human sociality and human capacity. In this way the history of machine learning is closely tied up with specific quantitative practices for imagining conceptions of democracy, representation, fairness, justice, and science in the United States. Accordingly, this dissertation contributes to a burgeoning study of distinct, locally-inflected forms of AI, pattern recognition, and machine learning across different geographies, cultures, and ideologies.

The use of machine learning systems to make social claims frequently depends on a historical understanding of machine learning as a subfield of AI. However, the co-PI's dissertation makes clear that machine learning developed prior to artificial intelligence, was co-eval to cybernetics, and that from the mid-1950s to late 1980s was centered largely on pattern recognition problems that were quite distinct from the primary concerns of artificial intelligence in that period. The failure to appreciate this history has contributed to the use of machine learning in social and political contexts where a machine learning system is unlikely to outperform prior methods. The dissertation contributes to a literature in the history of statistics and technology that examines how changing practices of counting and measuring inform changing conceptions of society, including how political and social problems are redefined and reconceived through technical practices. This history of machine learning provides an opportunity to understand how statistical measures are used to define and to measure the "efficacy" of policies, and so contributes to larger ongoing discussions in the social sciences and to contemporary debates about the role of government subsidization and regulation of technology.
